Join us for a fun and instructive morning celebrating the upcoming holidays as we create our own seasonal goodies and share some "me" time over coffee. Your little ones are welcome, as well.  We have an almost 2 year old who's spearheading the event! 


We will learn how to incorporate essential oils into our body care and home products when we make our own:
-Bath Salts ~ Orange Spice Bath Salts with orange and cinnamon
-Sugar Scrub ~ Peppermint sugar scrub bars
-Lip Balms ~ "Candy Cane" with peppermint and vanilla
-Room Sprays ~ "The 12 Sprays of Christmas" (choose your own holiday scent)

You can choose to make three products for $12 or make all four for $15 (to cover material costs). If you just want to observe and enjoy some company, you're welcome, too!

We will make sure everyone leaves feeling merry & bright!

**Please RSVP with how many people are coming and how many batches of goodies you'd like to make.  We will take payments at the event.**

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Prof. Larry Temkin, a moral philosopher (ethicist) at Rutgers (in New Jersey), will give a talk entitled "Global Poverty: Why Should We Care?" on Monday afternoon at 4pm in Harvard Square, Cambridge (see poster). 

Prof. Temkin is one of today's leading moral philosophers.
If your motivation for pursuing your career is largely altruistic, this talk may offer a chance to reflect on your choices and motives.

Some students may not be aware of the "Effective Altruism" movement, which has become a very interesting development. It has two premises. The first is that each of us ought to share more of our personal resources with those who are desperately in need. The second is that if one is prepared to donate, it makes sense to donate effectively, i.e., in a way that will have an important impact on relieving suffering. Remarkably, this second premise is not commonly shared even among those active in the non-profit world, or among philanthropists. A young hedge-fund would-be philanthropist was so amazed by this that he created www.givewell.com, an organization that assess the impact of aid organizations (measured in DALYs). (You can hear his story here.) 

This idea spread quickly.  Soon it attracted the attention of a young Oxford philosopher, Toby Ord, who had founded www.givingwhatwecan.org, which has also been highly influential, not least among Harvard undergraduates. 

You know Toby's work from the WHO report on equity in Universal Health Coverage; he invented the priority-setting method that was the subject of a remarkable book about altruism and altruists, Strangers Drowning: Grappling with Impossible Idealism, Drastic Choices, and the Overpowering Urge to Help, has just been published.  The author is Larissa MacFarquhar, a staff writer for The New Yorker. It is a portrait of a number of people who take the needs of strangers to be as important as their own, and tries to understand the sources and explanation of their remarkable selflessness. 

If you have wondered about this in your own case, you might be interested in a reading from the book available as a podcast here or in text form here.

Interested in joining Harvard Effective Altruism? Their link is here.
results.name: Prof. Larry Temkin, Rutgers ethicist: "Global Poverty: Why Should We Care?"

Release Date:

December 11, 2015


Rating:

PG-13


Synopsis:

Oscar winner Ron Howard (“A Beautiful Mind”) directs the action adventure “In the Heart of the Sea,” based on Nathaniel Philbrick’s best-selling book about the dramatic true journey of the Essex. In the winter of 1820, the New England whaling ship Essex was assaulted by something no one could believe: a whale of mammoth size and will, and an almost human sense of vengeance. The real-life maritime disaster would inspire Herman Melville’s Moby-Dick. But that told only half the story. “In the Heart of the Sea” reveals the encounter’s harrowing aftermath, as the ship’s surviving crew is pushed to their limits and forced to do the unthinkable to stay alive.

https://youtu.be/YcSZquiCT48

results.description:
Are you looking for new tools in your tool box to manage cumbersome spreadsheets? Wondering if there's an Excel formula that could improve your life?Join Socializing for Justice for a ProfDev on Intermediate Excel Tips & Tricks on Monday, December 7th from 6:00-8:30 PM. Learn new Excel magic that you'll be able to apply right away!

Fee: $10 advance/ $20 door is split with the trainers.
Limited space - register ahead of time: www.sojust.org
Credit cards accepted online. Cash only at the door.
Newcomers always welcomed!

*This is a fragrance-free event. Please do not wear fragrances (scented lotions,  perfumes, etc.) or smoke just prior to attending. Thank you.*

Intermediate Excel Tips & Tricks
 This session caters for Microsoft Excel users who are proficient in the basics, but looking at extending their knowledge and skills beyond creating simple workbooks.  It is designed to improve user’s productivity within Excel, including techniques to achieve quick results and more efficient workbooks easier to maintain.  Skills include charts (what type to use when), conditional formatting, using lookup/match/if functions, hyperlinks, and  fancy formulas.

ABOUT OUR PRESENTER
Stephany George has been learning and exploring with Excel since her first college-level biology course in 2007.  After seeing the multitude of uses, she has focused on learning as much about Excel as possible to make data entry and sorting a simpler process. She holds a MPA in non-profit management and uses her knowledge to help anyone that asks.  Stephany currently works as a Campus Activities Coordinator and Residence Director at Newbury College. Follow her: @StephanyAGeorge.


SCHEDULE
6:00-6:30 Socializing - bring your own dinner
 6:30-8:30 Training and Q&A

DIRECTIONS - The NonProfit Center is located one block from South Station at 89 South Street. The Center is physically accessible through the main lobby.

____________________________________________________

Socializing for Justice - www.sojust.org
Since 2006, we've been building this great sandbox where we can bring progressives of all stripes together and try out new ideas in this "Movement Moment". Spaces like this are crucial as we start to reframe and build new visions for our movement(s).

SoJust hosts events that draw progressives of all stripes that share common values but may work on different issues. We host monthly socials that allow for the possibility of cross-issue connections and run a monthly ProfDev Series, hosted by The NonProfit Center*, which provides access to affordable professional development to increase our individual capacity for movement building.

With over 2800 members and 9 years of creating a diverse cross-issue community in Boston (200+ events!), Socializing for Justice is the best place to find the great people, organizations and community you're looking for while putting the SOCIAL back in social justice.

YES, WE MEAN YOU. We've got members of all ages, races, genders, sexual orientations, levels of activism and professions. We hope you see someone like yourself and meet someone you otherwise wouldn't have.
results.name: ProfDev: Intermediate Excel Tips & Tricks

results.description:
What if you could time travel to 1915 Paris and meet one of the world's most renowned scientists? Join StoryCode Boston and MIT Open Documentary Lab as we celebrate Nobel Prize week and host the first feedback screening of Humanity Needs Dreamers: A Visit With Marie Curie, a Boston-based film production of the one-act play exploring narrative science through living history theater.


The production was featured recently on NPR's Living Lab to which you can listen here.


Two-time Nobel Prize winner Marie Skłodowska-Curie is best known for coining the term radioactivity. Discovering two elements and pioneering new fields of study in both chemistry and physics, her work paved the way for the first radiation treatments for cancer — but few understand the obstacles she faced just to get into the laboratory.

Artfully portrayed by living history scholar & playwright Susan Marie Frontczak, Humanity Needs Dreamers: A Visit With Marie Curie invites audiences of all ages to experience Marie’s remarkable journey from her childhood in Poland to her groundbreaking scientific research in France.


Along with exploring best practices in filming a live production, this project offers a unique opportunity to explore the contrasts and connections between the language of cinema and theater. Screening is 45 minutes and will be followed by a Q & A with filmmakers Jen Myronuk (Producer & Director) and Johnathan Carr (Cinematographer & Editor).
results.how_to_find_us: Enter MIT at 77 Mass Ave (Rogers Building), walk through lobby, and down a long hallway. At second stairwell (Building 4), turn right and walk down that hallway through Building 4 to Building 2. Room 105 is at the end of that hallway to the left.
results.name: "Humanity Needs Dreamers: A Visit With Marie Curie" Preview Screening and Q&A

results.description:
Our speaker this month will be Faith Girdler – Inveterate World Traveler - 

She will talk about one of her favorite countries – Chile - which she has visited many times while witnessing its conversion into one of South Americas successful democracies. It is also a great place to visit during the winter!


Faith grew up in Connecticut but soon after college developed a lifestyle for which the word “wanderlust” would be an understatement. Somehow since then , in spite of living on a smallish income, she has managed to not only visit but live in most of the countries of the world including China, Russia, India, Egypt, North Africa, Europe, South Africa, South America, Mexico, Australia, New Zealand, North Pole, South Pole and etc. etc. etc.! She has circumnavigated the world many times and can say “Please, Thank You, and @##!!$%! In at least a dozen languages!


She lived in Europe for the 1st time in the late 1980s, arriving in Germany to see the collapse of the Berlin Wall. A year in Tuscany followed, and also managed a year in Prague, Czech Republic , just in time to watch that country split into 2 separate countries.
After returning to the US in 1995, a stint in graduate school followed. It wasn't until 2001, however, that a harried travel agent inadvertently launched her on her current obsession ...Latin America. He had to get back to work, so told her to close her eyes, he would spin the globe and she had to agree to go wherever her finger landed.
Fortunately, it was Peru, and after her 1st trip, it was love at 1st sight. She now spends 4 months every year since then (January-April), getting to know what really is her 2nd home. Peru and Chile are her 2 favorites, as she has witnessed all kinds of fascinating political and cultural events over the decades plus of travel.

About the Dinner: Usually about 20 to 35 people composed of members and meetup invitees.

Social Hour: 6:00 p.m. Dinner: 6:30 p.m. Speaker : Around 8 p.m. 

You can come at any time.

RISTORANTE GRAN GUSTO

We have negotiated two reduced (!) price dinners. However if neither of these suit you you can order separately from their menu or not at all!

The two dinner choices are: A many(!) course Italian dinner at $36.00 or a pizza, appetizer, salad and desert dinner at $24.00. (The pizza is real authentic Italian pizza!) (tip included!) Or you can join the club and pay less per dinner!

Drinks can be ordered from the bar.
results.how_to_find_us: Plenty of Parking in the rear of the building. Enter through the iron arch and proceed behind the building to the left.
results.name: Chile Out (South America) History and Travelogue and Dinner

PLEASE RSVP SO WE CAN CONFIRM WE HAVE NUMBERS FOR THE GAME.


6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
ALERT!

We will be pulling folks from the audience again tonight!

If you are interested in sharing your experiences in:

(a) Co-Founder/ Key Employee Stories

(b) Solution Definition/ Development Stories

(c) Target Market Identification Engagement Stories

(d) Financing/ Funding Stories

(e) Exit Stories

Ping me here or on my cell --[masked] -- ID yourself and the topic(s) you would consider sharing fireside

>>> <<< >>> <<< >>> <<< >>> <<<


IoT Startup 2.0? What happened to 1.0?

(1) You do not need to roll your own stack.

(2) Enough hardware incubators have progressed -- led by Bolt -- that hardware is now only hard, not next to impossible.


(3) Privacy is not dead, security is not a red herring, we have to grow up and not worry about being cool to meet the market where it is, or lead it.


We need 100 current, recent, and soon-to-be Founders, Co-Founders and C-levels from startups working in IoT.


We will have a handful of experienced early stage investors and strategic partner types joining a handful of experienced IoT leaders in a series of discussions around what it takes to fund and scale your IoT startup.

No cookbooks. No magic dust. No hype.


Attendance is limited to 100, please:

(1) Check your professional history for IoT-specific startup experience.


(2) Check your IoT-specific startup experiences for what you can share.


(3) Check your IoT-specific goals for what you want to learn.


If you have relevant and strong answers in all three, RSVP, if not, consider waiting a few days ... let some others hop in ...


More coming ...
results.name: Meetup #40: IoT Startup 2.0. In it? Bring it! Dinner is on Radius Partners

Yes, it's Drink, Draw and Tacos again. Join us at the tasty, quirky, funky Once Lounge at Cuisine En Locale. Draw on your own or get instructions while enjoying farm to table tacos and a nice cocktail or brew. We would love to see you there.

In other news, Boston Sketching could use your help, and here are three ways that you can ensure our future awesomeness.

1. I am looking for a co-organizer or two to help create and maintain Boston Sketching meetups. 

2. Have you considered chipping in to support us as we create opportunities for you to get together with other sketchers, develop your skills with workshops and seminars and find you new locations, sponsors and more. In the last few months we went from under 500 members to over 1,500 members. We are counting on a few of you to chip in $5 bucks would be great, $10 bucks would be awesome and anything more would be just short of amazing! It takes time, talent and networking to keep the group going and we appreciate any amount you can pitch in to support the fun.

3. We are always looking for new locales and new ideas for MeetUps, so if you have an idea, please let us know.

results.description:
Come learn about Crowdsourcing and Open Science in the field of neurotechnology from our amazing speakers/panelists.

This is a FREE event for entrepreneurs, hackers, enthusiasts and experts to drive innovation and foster collaboration on Neurotechnology : Brain-Computer Interfaces, Wearables, Virtual Reality, Artificial Intelligence, 3D Game for mapping neurons, Open-Source Innovation of human-computer interfaces technologies.

http://www.meetup.com/NeuroTechBOS/events/226781563/

Agenda:

6:30 - 6:45: Registration and networking

6:45 - 7:00: Welcome and Introduction to NeuroTechX (Yannick Roy)

7:00 - 7:30: EyeWire and the future of citizen neuroscience (Amy Robinson)

7:30 - 8:00: The OpenBCI platform and the current state of DIY Neuroscience (Conor Russomanno)

 --- 5 Minute Break ---

8:05-8:35: Panel discussion on community, open science, and crowdsourcing in neurotechnology and neuroscience. (Yannick Roy, Amy Robinson, Connor Russomanno, Daniel Goodwin)

8:35-10:00: OpenBCI and EyeWire Demos, Networking

------------------------

Speaker Biographies

Yannick Roy: Executive Director, NeuroTechX Strong believer in human-enhancement, Yannick earned his bachelor degree in electrical engineering and is now doing his PhD in neuroscience at Université de Montreal. Excited by emerging technology like Brain-Computer Interfaces, Wearables, Virtual Reality and Artificial Intelligence and entrepreneur by nature, Yannick is eager to leave his mark and impact lives of thousands of people with neurotechnologies.

Amy Robinson: Executive Director, EyeWire

Amy Robinson is an expert in crowdsourcing. She is the Executive Director of EyeWire, a game to map the brain played by nearly 200,000 people worldwide. In EyeWire, gamers solve 3D puzzles that map out neurons, allowing neuroscientists to chart synaptic connections among neurons and thus begin to decipher the mysteries of how we see. EyeWire is the first of many games that will invite the world to make discoveries about how the brain works. Amy is a long time TEDster and founded the TEDx Music Project, a collection of the best live music from TEDx events around the world. She was named to the Forbes 30 Under 30 in 2015.

Conor Russomanno: Co-Founder & CEO, OpenBCI

Conor is the co-founder & CEO of OpenBCI, a company dedicated to open-source innovation of human-computer interfaces technologies. Having received a BS in civil engineering and engineering mechanics from Columbia University and an MFA in Design & Technology from Parsons School of Design, Conor is now an adjunct faculty at both Parsons and NYU's ITP program. Conor has dedicated the first phase of his career to interfacing the human brain and body, rethinking the idea of what it means to be a successful business, and turning crazy ideas into realities. OpenBCI Kickstarter #2 is currently underway!

Daniel Goodwin: Author of "Neuroscience Needs Hackers"

Dan is currently working towards his PhD in Ed Boyden's Synthetic Neurobiology group. As someone who once left science to build a career in Silicon Valley, he returned to academia to blend the worlds of scientific pursuit and entrepreneurial thinking. He left the PhD track at Stanford to become an Entrepreneur-In-Residence at the global design firm IDEO, then became the co-founder/CTO of Mobile Data Labs (now a thriving 25-person company). He left the company to invest his career in neurotech, and was a research scientist in computational neuroscience at the Simons Center for Data Analysis in Manhattan before enrolling at the MIT Media Lab to work with Dr. Boyden.

-----------------

About WeWork

WeWork is a community for creators. We transform buildings into beautiful, collaborative workspaces and provide infrastructure, services, events and technology so our members can focus on doing what they love. We currently have 55 locations in seventeen cities with over 34,000 members. Book a tour at wework.com.

------------------

More to Read: Hacking the Brain — Restoring Lost Abilities With the Latest Neurotechnologies

results.description:
I hope you will come out to our Christmas / Holiday Party.


We will be ordering plenty of food from the Lir's wonderful "Bar Bites" menu, so bring your appetite and "ugly sweater" (for an ugly sweater contest) and enjoy good cheer and fellowship with like minded people.


We can also celebrate the major milestone for the Common Core ballot initiative - 80,000 signatures were turned in on Wednesday to the Secretary of State's office!

We can also discuss issues of the day: the climate change conference, the upcoming presidential primaries, the budget, the new Speaker of the House, and much more.

Also over the next two months we will be inviting representatives from the various presidential campaigns to come talk to us, to make their "pitch".  We will be polling people to see who they are most interested in hearing from.


I hope to see you there!

---------------------------------------------- Traditional Boston Meeting notes:

We will again have a social hour at 6:30 pm and have the meeting begin at 7:30 pm.

Parking – from Parkopedia. It appears the Dalton Street garage is the best value, with a flat rate of $15 in the evening. Note the green lines denote on-street parking. You need to go to a meter pay station to get slip for your car – pay up to 8 pm.

Parkopedia:  http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/bar/lir-ma/

NOTE: As always with Boston parking, things are subject to change. Special events will cause parking lots to hike their prices, and we do not check in advance to see if there are any such occurrences coming up.
results.name: Boston - GBTP Christmas / Holiday Party

venue.name: Zen Muscular Therapy and Wellness Center

results.description:
Discover the holistic benefits of the Feldenkrais Method®!

Each 90 minute Awareness Through Movement class consists of guided attention through carefully sequenced movements that are designed to stimulate your curiosity, challenge your coordination, and bring you into a new way of being in both body and mind. 

By encouraging us to slow down, reduce effort, and delve into the building blocks of our movement, Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement enables us to discover previously unnoticed areas of habitual tension and unlock new possibilities for moving freely. Come and experience for yourself what an effective resource it can be for stress relief, improving balance and posture, and alleviating chronic pain at the source. 

Classes are open to adults at all fitness levels. No prior experience necessary. Drop-ins are welcome, but RSVPing will give you the opportunity to influence the content of the class for your needs and interests! 


Dress comfortably and bring a yoga or pilates mat. We have a few extra available.
results.name: Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement class!

venue.name: Gran Gusto and The Atrium at the Brickyard Office Park

results.description:
Dinner: 6:30 p.m, Social Hour: starts at 6:00 p.m. Speaker: Around 8 p.m. Arrive any time.


Plenty of Parking in the rear of the building. Enter through the iron arch and proceed behind the building to the left. Or a short 10-minute walk from Porter Square.


OUR SPEAKER

Faith Girdler – Inveterate World Traveler

She will talk about one of her favorite countries – Chile – which she has visited many times while witnessing its conversion into one of South America's successful democracies. It is also a great place to visit during the winter!

Faith grew up in Connecticut but soon after college developed a lifestyle for which the word “wanderlust” would be an understatement. Somehow since then, in spite of living on a smallish income, she has managed to not only visit but live in most of the countries of the world including China, Russia, India, Egypt, North Africa, Europe, South Africa, South America, Mexico, Australia, New Zealand, North Pole, South Pole, etc.! She has circumnavigated the world many times and can say “Please, Thank You, and @##!!$%! In at least a dozen languages!

She lived in Europe for the first time in the late 1980s, arriving in Germany to see the collapse of the Berlin Wall. A year in Tuscany followed, and also managed a year in Prague, Czech Republic, just in time to watch that country split into 2 separate countries. 

After returning to the US in 1995, a stint in graduate school followed. It wasn't until 2001, however, that a harried travel agent inadvertently launched her on her current obsession... Latin America. The travel agent had to get back to work, so told her to close her eyes, he would spin the globe and she had to agree to go wherever her finger landed. 

Fortunately, it was Peru, and after her first trip, it was love at first sight. She now spends 4 months every year (January-April) getting to know what really is her second home. Peru and Chile are her 2 favorites, as she has witnessed all kinds of fascinating political and cultural events over her decades of travel.

ABOUT THE DINNER

Usually about 20 to 35 people composed of members and meetup invitees.

RISTORANTE GRAN GUSTO

We have negotiated two reduced (!) price dinners. However if neither of these suit you you can order separately from their menu or not at all!

The two dinner choices are: A multi-course Italian dinner at $36.00 or a pizza, appetizer, salad and dessert dinner at $24.00. (The pizza is authentic Italian pizza!) (tip included!) If you join the club, you pay less per dinner!

Drinks can be ordered from the bar.
results.name: Chile Out (South America) History and Travelogue and Dinner

Neiel Israel is an internationally acclaimed poet, vocalist, performer and arts educator.
Emerging from the Boston spoken‐word scene, she quickly distinguished herself as a powerful,
and lyrical poetic voice. With her captivating voice she became a member of the
Lizard Lounge National Poetry Slam Team 2011‐2015; as well as the Lizard Lounge

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.


BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:


1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.  Finally, if there are unusual circumstances, you can send Tucker a message.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

Update (10/15): In order to accommodate more people in the room, and maintain an easygoing environment for conversation and game playing, we ask that you please save loud games (like those with real-time arguing) for later in the evening, when the room is less full.  Typically this means 9:30 or later.


OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.

results.description:
On Monday, December 7th, we'll be reviewing David Wheeler's script, Rhapsody in Mind.

Log Line: Electronic poltergeists infest a family's home, causing interference, then malicious control, and ultimately, attacks on national security. 

David is a jack of all trades. He works as a marketing professor at Suffolk University and when he's not there, he teaches sailing at Community Boating on the Charles. He also has his pilot's license and just recently piloted an ultralight aircraft from Carson City Airport to the Sierra Nevada. There, he skimmed the waters of Lake Tahoe and returned, making the distance he flew the same as from Great Falls National Park to Andrews Air Force Base.

In addition to being a man of many talents, David has also seen, and lived in, various parts of the world. He spent decades living in Lubbock, TX until he met a young woman who changed his life. She said, "You've got to see the world before you die," and so he did just that. He moved to New York City, then to San Francisco, and to Bangkok after that. Now, David resides on Beacon Hill in Boston.

The meeting will be held at 66 Winthrop Street in Cambridge, at 7:00 p.m. Dues are $15.
results.name: Script Review for David Wheeler's Rhapsody in Mind

results.description:
Gold and Bronze Memberships entitle you to attend great events like this one! Please visit our Membership Levels Page to become a Bronze or Gold Member.


Bill Gates recently said, "I am in the camp that is concerned about super intelligence. First, the machines will do a lot of jobs for us and not be super intelligent. That should be positive if we manage it well. A few decades after that, though, the intelligence is strong enough to be a concern. I agree with Elon Musk and some others on this and don't understand why some people are not concerned."

Anyone who has read Chapter 8 of Ray Kurzweil's book, The Singularity Is Near will be concerned, too. Let's discuss how to set up proper defenses before it's too late! Or just enjoy one of Panera's fabulous bread bowls and hope for the best. Either way, please join us, prepared with something you've read on the subject (anything from Kurzweil's book to one of the many stories in the news lately).

The requisite Membership Level for this event is Bronze or above, and must be paid or acquired before you RSVP. DO NOT RSVP BEFORE PAYING (Click Here). 

Here are some questions we might consider. Even if you haven't read the book, feel free to weigh in!

Do you worry about the “gray goo scenario” (runaway self-replication of nanobots)? If so, how do you see it playing out? For example, what kind of person or group would initiate it?

Kurzweil says the window for a gray goo attack will close in the 2020s, when strong AI will come to our defense, but then we must worry about the threat from strong AI. What do you think of this?

The open-source software movement seeks to improve security through transparency. The idea is that if a system is exposed to all, then someone will detect and fix defects and security holes. And this seems to work. Do you think this sort of transparency would improve our defenses against runaway GNR (genetics, nanotechnology and robotics), or do you think we would be better off with secrecy and strict regulation? Do you think it’s possible that nanobots that are so small as to be “undetectable” could also be so capable that they could “monitor, influence and even control thoughts and actions”? Before you say “No,” recall earlier chapters, where Kurzweil showed how much computation can be done with very limited amounts of material, properly arranged.

Do you think it’s possible to relinquish certain aspects of technological progress, yet continue to make progress in other areas?

What comfort or dread can we derive from our successes and failures in combating super-destructive computer viruses such as stuxnet?

What do you think of Kurzweil’s characterization of “fundamentalist humanism,” which he defines as “opposition to any change in what it means to be human (for example, changing our genes and taking other steps toward radical life extension)”?
results.name: Futurology Study Group: Defending Against the Perils of the Singularity

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

Science and Cooking - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public. 

:: :: ::

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

:: :: ::


These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Hall C) and begin at 7 p.m. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s class. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) results.description:
Our feelings and emotions are reliable guides that tell us a lot about what's going on with us.  For any one of us, at any moment, several emotions are co-existing, ready to teach us about ourselves.


As children, most of us were still raised with the expectation that we should be "nice little girls."  As we grew older, we may have swallowed or even denied our own anger and frustration -- two legitimate but not "nice" emotions -- to our detriment.  Or, if we allowed ourselves to be angry, it was on behalf of others such as our friends and loved ones, where we could become a fierce mama bear.


Anger and frustration can also often be powerful teachers and catalysts to get us moving.  They can signal what needs attention in our lives, for example, our own attitudes or external circumstances that require changing.

Let's think and talk about all of the above and the ways anger and frustration can be utilized for fuel that can propel us forward out of old patterns and being stuck. 


There is always a 10-minute guided meditation at the end of the discussion.

Also, over the last several months, it has become a tradition for those of us so inclined to continue our conversation up the street at JP Licks immediately following the monthly discussion.

Please remember to avoid using scented personal products before coming to the meetup as some of our members are chemically sensitive.

A contribution of $5 (or whatever you can afford) toward the meeting room rental and organizer fee is greatly appreciated.  And please change your RSVP before 7 p.m. if you are unable to attend.

There is free parking after 6 p.m. in the lot across the street from the church. To find us, enter the last door on the right at the end of the driveway at the side of the church.

results.description:
{Every great story has a great antagonist -- a force that drives transformative change. What if climate change is the force driving us to transform in ways that align with our deepest values? And what if you are alive at this evolutionary moment because you have an essential role to play?} 

What to Expect

Tonight you will experience an excerpt from Marianne Connor's new workshop, Using the Power of Story for Transformative Change, which she is developing to spur individuals and communities into action to help create the future we want. You will get to engage with the workshop material itself, as well as provide feedback on what works and what doesn’t, and what evokes the most compelling story for stepping into big change.

A Description of the Workshop

"We have it in our power to begin the world over again. A situation, similar to the present, hath not happened since the days of Noah until now. The birthday of a new world is at hand…" -- Thomas Paine, Common Sense

We are living in transformative times. The opportunities for deep structural social change are very likely to occur in our lifetimes -- brought to us by climate change and the end of cheap fossil fuels.

Whether we use the opportunity of transformative change to create the future we want or “double-down” on a future of fear, scarcity, environmental destruction and social inequality will be largely determined by our choice to step into transformative change by conscious, creative design rather than wait for outside events to force us to change.

"We are called to be architects of the future, not its victims." -- R. Buckminster Fuller

So, how do we inspire ourselves and each other into transformative change? And how do we change in ways that are creative and generative? This is where the power of story can act as an essential catalyst. Time and time again in human history, we have proven that we are willing to risk everything for the things that matter most in life -- if we really believe we can make a difference. The compelling story lets us know we matter and why.

By working in partnership with Nature, we can create an abundant, equitable and democratic future for the 21st Century, while healing and regenerating life on our precious home planet. Many are already engaged in this process, so let’s create the story that moves us into action!

Come learn about the structure of transformative change, uncover the unconscious stories that keep you from stepping into change by choice, and grow the story that inspires you to create the world anew!

To Prepare ....

Let this 7-minute video, A New Story of the People, bring forth your inspiration for our conversation together: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2wviYuKDlKs

Consider the question: How can we live in service to the “More Beautiful World Our Hearts Know is Possible?"

If you’ve got more time, David Korten does a great job of articulating the major cultural stories of our time in this article:

http://www.yesmagazine.org/pdf/kortennewstory.pdf


Our Leader This Evening

Marianne Connor is a screenwriter/producer/educator and 21st Century story designer. Most on purpose for her now is creating the stories that provoke and inspire the creation of a life-giving, equitable and democratic world.

She is currently developing Earth Works! -- a reality television show that reveals ways to design our lives to regenerate the planet and reverse climate change. She teaches her 21st Century Story Design workshop to screenwriters internationally in graduate programs in Finland, Britain and Germany. In 2011, she completed a Master's in Sustainable Systems at Bainbridge Graduate Institute in Seattle. She holds an MFA in Film & Media Arts from Temple University in Philadelphia and a BS in Foreign Service from Georgetown University in Washington, DC.

https://marianneconnor.wordpress.com/

What if climate change is the force driving us to transform ourselves and our world into the future aligned with our deepest, heartfelt values? And what if you are alive at this evolutionary moment because you have an essential role to play in that transformation?

results.description:
Does car seat installation frustrate you?  Have you ever wondered if your car seat was installed properly?  What is the safest way to transport your children in a Taxi cab?


Please join us for a relaxed, informative, and FREE evening workshop for members of the Boston Dads Group, featuring Sarah Tilton, BRITAX Child Passenger Safety Technician.

Expect to walk away as an expert when it comes to your child’s car-seat safety and safely transporting your children in and outside the city.  When the learning ends, we hope you’ll stick around and hang out while enjoying a few beverages 

Refreshments will be served + Car Seat Giveaways  (Several Dads will be going home with brand new car seats!)

What: 

Social Media Event Hashtag:  #BRITAXSafety

Workshop Time: 7:30pm - 8:45pm, Hang out/Beverages to follow until 9pm

Location: Little Lovage Club in the South End. Special thanks to Little Lovage Club (LLC) for hosting this evening discussion and Britax for sponsoring it.

Cost: FREE

Who: Members of the Boston Dads Group Community

Other: Expect awesome giveaways from Britax!  Several dads will be going home with a brand new car seat.

Topics of discussion, include, but are not limited to: 

• Are you using your car seat correctly?

· How to tell if you are using the right car seat for your child

· Properly securing your child in a car seat

· Checking your car seat installation

· Car seat expiration dates

• The First Car Ride: Bringing Baby Home Safely

• Your Toddler's Next Seat: How to Choose the Right Convertible Car Seat 

• Forward Facing vs Rear Facing in a Car Seat

•  Are you confused about LATCH (Lower Anchors and Tethers for Children)?

o There's so much conversation among caregivers regarding LATCH - weight capacities, when can it be used, how long can it be used. 

o Highlight LATCH requirements and what the new labeling will mean to you as a caregiver using a car seat with LATCH. 

• Open Discussion on using Public Transportation with Children 

· Taxis 

· Planes

· Trains, Subways, and Buses

· Rental Cars 

Who is Sarah Tilton?

Sarah Tilton is the Child Passenger Safety Advocate for BRITAX Child Safety, Inc. As an active CPS Technician (2002 and Instructor (2004), Sarah is the spokesperson for BRITAX within the advocacy community participating in child passenger safety activities at a local, state and national level. Sarah serves on the new product development, technical writing and marketing teams at BRITAX.  In addition, she managed and developed the training curriculum for the BRITAX Consumer Services department and organized and implemented a permanent checking station at BRITAX during 11+ years with the company.  Sarah is currently active with the Safe Kids South Carolina, Safe Kids York County (SC), Safe Kids North Carolina, and Charlotte Mecklenburg (NC) coalitions. She is also a member of the NC Child Passenger Safety Training Committee and the National Child Passenger Safety Board representing the At Large population and the Vice-Chair of the Manufacturers Alliance for Child Passenger Safety.

**Disclosure Note: This is a sponsored event with Britax/BOB in which we have received compensation. We limit our advertising to relevant partners that offer products and services we believe in and use ourselves. **
results.name: Evening Workshop: Child Passenger/Car Seat Safety with Britax (Free Car Seats!)

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.

results.description:
Why is sex awkward to talk about? What does it mean to be “normal” in regard to sex, and is it worth striving toward? How can you learn to love your sexual personality? In this participatory discussion-based workshop, we will talk about the ways in which our culture pressures us to fit our sexuality into a box, and what you can do to overcome that pressure by accepting and cultivating your own unique sexual personality. There will be a focus on moving beyond fear, shame, and embarrassment toward openness, confidence, and an attitude of self-love.

Buy tickets here:
http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2304526
Tickets are $20 in advance, $25 at the door.


This is Nicole's second workshop at Good Vibrations, and she's really excited and honored to have the opportunity to lead this workshop there. Please come out and support!


This is for people of all genders.

When attending or registering please let Nicole know you heard about the event from the Pleasure Without Borders Meetup. Thanks!

Accessiblity info:
Good Vibrations is wheelchair accessible. There are a few handicap specific parking spots in the Centre Street lot that are very close to the front door. The front door is rather heavy and can be difficult to open (if it's a concern, you are welcome to call from outside and an employee will come hold the door open). It is also a relatively small space, but tables and fixtures can be moved out of the way if needed. The store complies with ADA standards regarding space left between walls and fixtures, so it may not be an issue at all.

Looking forward to seeing you there! :)

Hello, beautiful members! I have received a great feedback for Therapeutic QiGong classes during Open Classes week at Zoom Zone, and so this form was chosen for our regular practice. 

It is definitely excellent for beginners and I am excited to teach all who are interested!

Our classes start this week, and will be offered 3 times a week( twice in the morning and once in the evening). 

I am offering 5 classes cards to buy with a free bonus this week(Dec 6th-12th), but if you can not commit to at least 5 classes, you are invited to try a class on any day listed bellow, and see if you would like to continue with the practice later.

Dates to try a class: 12/8th, 12/10th, 12/15th, 12/17th, 12/22th 2015.

NO CLASSES: 12/24th, 29th, 31th.

Classes will resume on January 5th, 2016!

----------------------------------------

QiGong is an ancient Chinese practice.

Easier than Taichi. Activates the body’s natural healing intelligence.

Excellent for recovery from surgery,  immune function, depression and cancer healing.

The Therapeutic QiGong routine combines 

• physical exercises, 

• gentle stretching, 

• breathing 

• self-massage 

• and full body relaxation.

The Chinese have practiced QiGong for centuries to enhance energy and blood circulation and prevent illness and rapid aging.

Therapeutic QiGong  improves your body and brain balance, relaxes your mind and muscles which results in a better sleep.

It is a wonderful practice for healing, anxiety and stress relief, developing good posture and balance, and recovery from injury and/or surgery.

Qi-Gong is easy, energizing, relaxing, healing and fun!

75 mins introduction class: warm-up,  energizing body tapping, slow Qi-Gong movements with proper breathing,  self-massage and relaxation.

Price:$18 - drop-in      $75 - 5 classes

Bonus - FREE INtroduction Into QiGong workshop (with 5 classes card purchase on the week of Dec.6th-12th)

more info:http://theintegratedway.com/qigong-yoga/therapeutic-qigong-taichi/

Recommended level: Beginner. This is an excellent preventative and recuperative exercise for all ages, and especially recommended for those who are 35+.

~ Questions? Contact Angela - QiGong instructor and club organizer

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
We will take a look at the FREE tools that you can use to maintain your privacy online, and discuss which ones are best for your needs.

Security and privacy - what does it mean to you in your everyday life? It used to be hard to use the tools that safeguard your identity and your information online. You had to be a pretty technical person - the good news is that it has gotten easier to be secure in your online persona.

These are some of the tools we will look at:

1. Off-the-Record (OTR) Messaging allows you to have private conversations over instant messaging.
2. Email Encryption using Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) is a data encryption and decryption computer program that provides cryptographic privacy and authentication for data communication. There is also the GnuPG system here: https://emailselfdefense.fsf.org/en
3. Tails is a live operating system, that you can start on almost any computer from a DVD, USB stick, or SD card. It aims at preserving your privacy and anonymity.

There are also some great apps for secure texting and secure phones that provide end-to-end encryption for your calls, securing your conversations so that nobody can listen in. There is no way to be bulletproof, but knowing about the options available can provide a measure of security. It is ultimately up to you to decide how much security you want.

Link to hangout: https://plus.google.com/hangouts/_/event/cjfhrydio4rhi9bpgih1coop154?hl=en

Question:

This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks? 

Answer:

• For this operation, there are "No qualifications - no limits!" 

Thanks to the efficiency and BI (business intelligence) of Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org), founded about 35 years ago by self-reported vegetarian Nancy Jamison, we have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food. 

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag). 

That's why it's posted on a meetup like this (not merely on a volunteer meetup). 

* There are tens of thousands of college students who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases. 
* There are tens of thousands (myriads) of homemakers and working individuals who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases. 
* Lots and lots of seniors AND needy folks, and there's no operational shame in prudent fiscal management if you know that you can get quality produce at a far lower price. 

[The snag is that, unlike in grocery stores - or even in Haymarket, your variety of produce is severely limited here because you're getting what Fair Foods sends to any specific site; you are unable to select from a broader arrangement of vegetables and a broader arrangement of fruits.  Typically, you get about 7-11 different items - about 5-8 different vegetables and 2-3 fruits, and you're often 'gifted' with extra items - 30 ounce jug of fresh hummus or lentil salad or chickpea salads, pound of garlic, large one-lb plastic container of ground pepper, or lots of other 'big items' we don't typically buy.] 

Make us busy - very busy.

She has built her career from both the sales operations perspective as well as a quota carrying sales rep, and has experience first hand the power of referrals and advocacy to generate outsize revenue growth.


About Emmanuelle:

As an “off the chart extrovert” she has always loved being in front of a crowd, engaging with customers and building teams. She has managed all facets of sales from Inside, Enterprise, Channel, Ops and Enablement. results.description:
Since 4th Tuesdays falls around holidays, we decided to combine November and December meetups into one. Please join us Tues. December 8,[masked]:00 PM at Bocoup Loft in downtown. We have two presentations on an open source pattern library/style guide tool called Pattern Lab. Pattern Lab is a tool to help create atomic design systems: http://patternlab.io/

---

"Why you NEED Pattern Lab"

Communicating the requirements from product owner/manager to designer to developer has been one of the most difficult workflows in development cycles. There are several reasons for this sometimes and unnecessarily contentious communication channel and relationship. The reasons range from stakeholders speaking different languages (some in code and some in colors and fonts), working in silos, ever-changing requirements not communicated properly from design to development or vice versa, and lacking transparency to design or development.

Some of these issues can be solved by setting proper design and development workflow and standardizations. However there are some principles and tools that can also help solve most of the above outlined strife. 

The principle of Atomic Design helps in breaking down the design into its modular and re-usable components. Pattern Lab is the tool that helps implement this principle. Through this principle and tool, we can promote better communication and transparency between the stakeholders. This presentation will demonstrate "the full power of this battle station!!" -- oops sorry, wrong quote -- "the full power of Pattern Lab".

About presenter: Kianosh Pourian is an user interface developer/UX and UI designer with 15+ years of experience in the web development industry. Founder and CEO of Cielo Concepts Inc, a small consultancy firm located in Boston, MA with clients like MIT, Harvard Business Review, Harvard Business School, and Perkin Elmer. He is also an advocate of the open web and heavily involved the development community of Boston. As the co-organizer of CASCADE BOS (a meetup around CSS in Boston), he believes in the open web and sharing his knowledge and experience with others. In his spare time, he enjoys coloring everything pink with his two daughters.

---

How Pattern Lab Solved Our Problem with Consistency. HBR.ORG story.

HBR pattern Lab project aims to develop a consistent style guide for HBR.org in a responsive environment. Our goal is to create a clear frame for collaboration between designers, developers, producers and web editors. The Pattern Lab approach introduces a a system of elemental, system-based, lego-like pieces our team uses to build new features that fit the big picture, that are user-centric and aligned with the Harvard Business Review brand. It’s an ongoing project, it grows as our site develops.

About presenters: Marta Kusztra is lead designer at Harvard Business Review, where she shapes the premium experiences of HBR.org and HBR’s mobile app and interactive tools. Marta manages all aspects of digital design from the visual approach to the interactive elements, to the processes used to continually create and update HBR’s digital presence. She has 20 years of experience in digital and physical product design. She has worked and lived in Poland, China, the United Kingdom and the United States and after two decades still loves what she does.

Laura Guillen is a Digital Designer at Harvard Business Review and works on the image assets, social media, interactives, and videos for HBR.org. After graduating a few years ago she gained experience by freelancing in varied companies and firms in Boston. Laura was born in Cuba but raised in Miami, Florida which means she’s still getting used to the Northeast weather.

--

Gathering and networking (pizza and refreshments courtesy of firstPRO Inc., Thank you!) at 6, talk starts at 7. 


Directions to 2 South Market St in Faneuil Hall Marketplace:
By MBTA: The closest T stops are Haymarket (Green and Orange lines) and State Street (Blue and Orange lines). From the Red Line, transfer at Park Street and take the Green Line to Haymarket.
By Car: Take exit 23 from I-93 North or exit 24A-24B from I-93 South.Parking: We recommend the 75 State Street Garage. You can buy discounted parking online at https://75statestreet.clickandpark.com/Once you've parked, the entrance to our office is in the Quincy Market South Market Building between Crabtree & Evelyn and Local Charm. There is a big sign with a number 2 on it!


-----


Cascade Bos is a community for tech-minded designers and design-savvy developers. We aim to be a community where members can learn from each other about ever-changing front-end technology and web design trends. Cascade Bos is run by volunteers.

results.description:
This meeting is sponsored by Akamai. 



Java and Microservices: Moving to Cloud Foundry and Bluemix

Part-1 Talk

Part-2 Hands on Lab will be in January

As the world moves towards more DevOps and microservices, application deployment to the cloud ought to become a lot simpler. The microservices architecture, which is the basis of many new age distributed systems such as OpenStack, NetFlix and so on, is at the heart of Cloud Foundry - a complete developer-oriented Platform as a Service (PaaS) that is IaaS agnostic and supports vCloud, OpenStack and AWS.


We will discuss the microservices architecture, 12-factor app, containers, etc., and how to architect applications for the cloud in general and Cloud Foundry in particular. Attend this demo-oriented session in which we will cover the basics of Cloud Foundry. He will also cover many of the Non Functional Requirements (NFR), which is typically in the domain of the architect such as scaling, security and HA and how applications can leverage Bluemix for these.


After attending this session, attendees will walk away with a better understanding of Platform as a Service and Cloud Foundry in general, and Bluemix in particular and how the ecosystem enables deploying applications to the cloud a lot easier. Attendees will also be able to understand how to enable logging, remote debugging, monitoring and so on by turning a few knobs in the platform.


Raghavan Srinivas

Raghavan "Rags" Srinivas (@ragss) works as an Architect/Developer Evangelist at IBM with a mission to help developers build highly scalable and available systems. His areas of focus are containers, Open Source and DevOps. His general interest is in distributed systems, with a specialization in Cloud Computing and Big Data. He worked on Cloud Foundry, OpenStack and Hadoop during its early stages. He has spoken on a variety of technical topics at conferences around the world, written for developer portals, and organized Hands-on Labs and taught graduate and online classes in the evening.


Rags brings with him over 25 years of hands-on software development and over 15 years of architecture and technology evangelism experience. He has evangelized and influenced the architecture of a number of emerging technology areas. He is also a repeat JavaOne rock star speaker award winner.


Rags holds a Masters degree in Computer Science from the Center of Advanced Computer

Studies at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. He likes to hike (has hiked the Everest Base Camp when he was a few pounds lighter), run and generally be outdoors but most of all loves to eat.
results.name: Java and Microservices: Moving to Cloud Foundry and Bluemix

results.description:
Join us at the Cambridge Semantics Web Monthly Meetup

Bankers and their IT staff around the world are facing at least another 5 years of regulatory scrutiny, small operating margins and understanding global systemic risk factors on their business model. As such, they are naturally reticent to look at "onomies" and "ologies" when they have little room for maneuver. This talk will discuss recent developments in the space and real world applications of semantic technology to deliver business value in the sector. Rupert Brown, Chief Technology Officer, Financial Services of MarkLogic will show you how leveraging the power of semantics inside a NoSQL database will provide a holistic view of customers, trades and transactions, and a complete Customer 360 view.

TO REGISTER, GO HERE: http://www.meetup.com/The-Cambridge-Semantic-Web-Meetup-Group/events/225607847/

While you are on-site, enter to win a Parrot AR Drone Quadricopter, 2.0 Elite Edition, 720p – it’s super cool!!!!

Additional location details: Rm 32-D463, 4th floor, Star Conference Room, Stata Center, MIT

results.description:
CALLING ALL New C&C Members!

                           Tonight is all about YOU

Bring your favorite game and show us how to play it or just come and meet some new people who share your same passion in game playing.

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford .  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play games.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: New Members Night in Medford
