results.description:
the “Hidden Market” of Real Estate, in the few years I’ve been with MassRealEstate.net I’ve found there is a Universal request for HELP finding “DEALS” from both beginning and seasoned members.

There are as many definitions of deals as there are members. My definition of a deal is a property that you can purchase at 75% or lower of the retail (MLS, Multiple Listing Service for Brokers) price. That pricing could be because of the Condition of the Property, the Situation of the Seller or the Status of the Market.

BUT

How do you find those Deals?

Tony Youngs will be presenting his BootCamp of  the “Hidden Market” in a Preview Friday 12/11/2015, evening 6:30pm at Denny’s of Danvers. This will be our regular meeting for December. No charge to Members, only $25. Guests or only $99/year to join.

Saturday, Sunday and Monday we’ll join Tony for his BootCamp Regularly priced at $1497. For MassRealEstate.net members only $997.

Here’s the Format:

We’ll begin Saturday morning at 9:00am sharp for an outline of the BootCamp and match up folks in our “convoy”. Over the three days we’ll visit at least 10 Foreclosures. But here’s the Hidden Market: Tony will uncover probably 20 other properties that fit his definition of Deals that YOU can make Offers on.

We’ll not only cover How these Deals are found but How to quickly Analyze and Make Offers on them.

What a great way to end 2015 on a high note and get ready for an even better Successful/Profitable 2016!

I look forward to seeing you Friday, Mike Hurney!

PS You can read all the material you want to, listen to 100 Podcasts, get on Blog Forums night and day BUT there is no comparison with getting out in the Field and joining an Expert like Tony Youngs
results.name: “Hidden Market” of Real Estate Friday 12/11/2015 6:30pm at Denny’s of Danvers

results.description:
A Film by Feriel Ben Mahmoud
(This event is free and open to the public)
On January 14th, 2011, the people of Tunisia took to the streets in mass protest and toppled the government of Ben Ali. The event has a tremendous impact in the region which helped trigger the Arab Spring. Following the revolution, Tunisians make the radical choice to draft a new state constitution. Called to the urns for the first free elections of their history, the citizens of Tunisia will have to choose which model of society they wish to live in. Islam, secularism and women’s status become the major themes of a campaign under high pressure.
Following the events day by day, TUNISIA, YEAR ZERO tells the story of a difficult birth: that of the first democracy in the Arab world. In 6 months, no less than 110 political parties were created. In this political turmoil, a few of them emerge: the Islamist party Ennhada seduces those disappointed with the revolution. Some other modernist parties, such as Ettakatol and the PDP, are divided on the content of their policies as well as on which strategy to adopt. Leading the polls, Ennahdha will confirm its success in the elections with more than 90 seats out of 217.
How could these results be predicted? TUNISIA, YEAR ZERO gives the reasons for the outcome of the elections.
results.name: December Film Screening at the CAC

7:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Luc Sante discusses The Other Paris. 


This event is free and includes a book signing; no tickets are required.

Friday, December 11th, 7pm

Harvard Book Store - 1256 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store welcomes award-winning author LUC SANTE for a discussion of his latest book, The Other Paris, a trip through Paris as it will never be again—dark and dank and poor and slapdash and truly bohemian Paris, the City of Light, the city of fine dining and seductive couture and intellectual hauteur, was until fairly recently always accompanied by its shadow: the city of the poor, the outcast, the criminal, the eccentric, the willfully nonconforming. In The Other Paris, Luc Sante gives us a panoramic view of that second metropolis, which has nearly vanished but whose traces are in the bricks and stones of the contemporary city, in the culture of France itself, and, by extension, throughout the world. Drawing on testimony from a great range of witnesses—from Balzac and Hugo to assorted boulevardiers, rabble-rousers, and tramps—Sante, whose thorough research is matched only by the vividness of his narration, takes the reader on a whirlwind tour. Richly illustrated with more than three hundred images, The Other Paris scuttles through the knotted streets of pre-Haussmann Paris, through the improvised accommodations of the original bohemians, through the whorehouses and dance halls and hobo shelters of the old city. 

A lively survey of labor conditions, prostitution, drinking, crime, and popular entertainment, and of the reporters, réaliste singers, pamphleteers, and poets who chronicled their evolution, The Other Paris is a book meant to upend the story of the French capital, to reclaim the city from the bons vivants and the speculators, and to hold a light to the works and lives of those expunged from its center by the forces of profit.

:: :: ::

Purchase the Book - Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked] 

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked]

results.description:
Do  mystical traditions have a role in rational life? I think that they do, but I'm not sure why. Perhaps my uncertainty exemplifies the topic because the answer may be that mysticism  may be important for some people but not for others.

****************************************


ADMISSION FEE:  Gold Members are admitted free.  All other members are required to pay a $5.50 admission fee, which is due on or before Dec. 1st.  PLEASE PAY HERE.  Any unpaid registrations as of Dec. 2nd will be changed to "not attending." After Dec. 2nd, please pay before registering your RSVP.

***************************************** 


There are many forms of mysticism: rich traditions that crisscross philosophy, spirituality and religion. I would say that the basic essence of mysticism is a belief and—more than belief, a  feeling or profound sense of awe that the whole universe is interconnected by One or a unity that many would call God, others a transcendent Mind, and others a universal consciousness in which all conscious beings participate. Also, in mysticism it is often claimed that states of reverie are achieved and said to be states of enlightenment. And, thus, here we have the basic theme for this discussion. From the point of view of philosophy, do mystical traditions and their meditative and ritual practices promote or help us discover wisdom and understanding? And does this understanding go beyond, or at least facilitate, valuable perspectives that philosophical thinking—or reason in general—have difficulty resolving or explaining.

As I mentioned, I think mysticism is important and valuable but my reasons are not clear in terms of specific principles or concrete examples. But, then, I don't think that mysticism is really intended to provide these things. Mysticism, in my view, is a collection of inspirational and creative metaphors that generate insight for the likes of scientists, philosophers and artists in any media. 'Metaphor' is probably not a good word for what I am trying to express, because while metaphor is certainly involved in mysticism, it does not do justice to the experiential profundity that is claimed, or the creativity that it clearly inspires.

There are many mystical traditions; here are a some of the major ones:  Kundalini yoga;  Hindu and Buddhist Tantra;  arguably Zen and Taoism;  Kabbalah;  Sufism;  Gnosticism;  Madam Blavatsky and Theosophy,  Gurdjieff and his student Ouspensky.  There are, I am sure, many other mystical orientations and traditions.

I hope that some of you will come to this meeting and share your mystical practices, traditions and perspectives or, on the other hand, discuss why you may feel that mysticism is not rational or, perhaps, even dangerous as a form of non-rational, anti-rational or irrational thinking. And I would welcome hearing from members who have particular experience and/or knowledge of mysticism and of particular mystical traditions. Or, again, I would welcome hearing from those who reject mysticism, or are perhaps excited about the potential of science to supplant it.


I cannot help thinking that there is a real convergence occurring in the modern age between science and mysticism. There is a very interesting anthology by Ken Wilber, Quantum Questions: Mystical Writings of the World's Great Physicists that includes writings of the great theoretical physicists of the twentieth century for e.g. Albert Einstein, Werner Heisenberg, and Max Planck. Almost all of them espoused mystical beliefs about the nature of the universe. In discussing the topic of the  technological  singularity  in the Futurology study group we have seen, I think, a convergence in which machine intelligence appears to be morphing into an organic, universal intelligence. This theme also occurs in recent movies such as Her and Lucy, which  conclude with human and/or machine intelligence merging into a collective consciousness that might be compared to what  some imagine as the mind of God.

During this dinner discussion, we will ponder the question of whether or not mysticism may be one of the solutions to the problems of humanity's present and future or, on the contrary,  a type of thinking that needs to be overcome.


GOLD MEMBERS ARE ADMITTED FREE.  ALL OTHER MEMBERS ARE REQUIRED TO PAY A $5.50 REGISTRATION FEE, WHICH IS DUE ON OR BEFORE DEC. 1st.  PLEASE PAY HERE.  ANY UNPAID REGISTRATIONS AS OF DEC. 2nd WILL BE CHANGED TO "NOT ATTENDING."  After Dec. 2nd, please pay before registering your RSVP.


********************************

The restaurant is directly across the street from the Kendal MBTA station.


Your admission fee does not include the cost of food and drink. Please be courteous by planning to pay for a full dinner, or a comparable amount in appetizer selections and, perhaps, a beverage. Members who attend this event and do not make a reasonable purchase disrespect the courtesy of the restaurant, and make it difficult for the Social Philosophizers Club to exist by compromising its ability reserve space for future events. Abuse of this privilege (such as telling the waitstaff, "Just a Coke please") will not be tolerated.


PLEASE PAY HERE

results.description:
Light painting is challenging and fun.  Make your subject the human body and you have a recipe for a fascinating and unusual evening.pour model will pose for us while we use a variety of flashlights to illuminate areas of skin to produce artful body-shapes. 

You will learn the techniques of body-painting with light which because of the subtle movement of the body produce interesting soft-focus images.

Varying the amount of "painting"  on parts of the body will highlight them or leave them in shadow. The trick is to control the amount of light to create these areas intentionally rather than by accident. 

Because of the nature of this technique, which requires complete darkness and long exposures from a tripod the number of participants will be limited to just four. 

The cost is $150.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter through the EMTS Inc door and head for 2nd floor. - call 339-499-8506 if lost.
results.name: Light painting the human body

results.description:
It is a wonderful thing to find a food and wine pair where each enhances the other. What's your favorite pairing?  Let's go on a quest to find wines to go with Cyril's wonderful, rich bouillabaisse.  It is a challenge!  The same panoply of flavors--saffron, seafood and tomatoes--that make bouillabaisse intriguing also make the obvious wine choices seem all wrong. Chardonnay might go with shrimp, but not with the sauciness of bouillabaisse. Cabernet and Bordeaux are wrong as well--too strong and tannic.  Cyril's search for a match suggests a Roussane-based wine from the Rhone Valley might be the answer, while others might seek a soft and juicy red.


Do some research, talk to your best wine merchant, or make a wild guess!  It will be a fun night and an enjoyable way to explore and learn about wines and what a difference a pairing can make.

Please bring a bottle of wine in a paper bag, 4 glasses, and an appetizer, side dish or dessert.
results.name: Bouillabaisse Roulette!

results.description:
Bhagavad Gita 1.36

Topic - War, Violence, Capital Punishment (Part 1)

We will learn about the qualities of "Tri-guna", the three energies of nature, in relation to war, conflict and violence. We will also cover the causes of war and violence according to the Gita and how they can be greatly minimized. We will also come to know what is this material realm and why, according to the Bhagavad Gita, war and violence cannot be eliminated in this realm.

We will cover the very detailed Vedic view regarding capital punishment; its true purpose, understanding its implementation, and discerning its relevance in modern society. Along with this discussion we will learn about the purpose of justice as defined by the Gita.
results.name: Bhagavad Gita Class

results.description:
Come join pro sound healer Sarah Turner fresh off her sound healing concert tour in California and myself for a heart opening sound healing! Really, its going to be the sound healing event of the season! If you only go to one sound healing a year, make it this one! Sarah is incredibly intuitive and knows how to work with the sound to allow you to have a transformative experience.

What do I mean when I say hearing the heart? No, not your heart beat ... but soul beat would be more accurate. Hehe. But anyway, I am clairaudient so I use this healing power to tune into your heart chakra and entrain it back to vibrate at its resonant frequency. I know that might raise an eyebrow but come and experience it and you'll feel what I mean ;)

So if you come to the Buddhist Temple for a sound healing, what can you expect?

When you come in, you take your shoes off, then you walk to the Dharma Hall which will be on your immediate right at the top of the stairs. We'll start with a short introduction and discuss each of our intentions for how we want to work with the sound and then meditate for a few minutes to tune into each of our specific intentions. The general theme will be answering the wake-up call to the divine presence ... And trust me, if you come, you will hear it ringing ; ) Then, everyone will sit or lie down on super comfy pillow mats (bring your own blanket/blindfold) and we'll begin our journey into sound.

I start by playing the 500 pound cast-iron temple bell and then I move into the sweet sounds of my Tibetan singing bowls. 

What follows, I can't exactly say, as the sound decides what it wants to say. But you can expect to hear the rainbow voice, the sound of the overtone chant singing with the tibetan bowls. You won't be able to tell which is which but this is all part of the dance. You will even feel what it's like to have the bowls played on you as the sound moves your energy where it needs to go. Tingshas, tuning forks, rattles and more are all part of the play as the sound moves you to rest at your destination without ever having moved. So, please, come and feel something unique. You never leave anywhere exactly the same, but when it comes to sound healing, you will leave sounding more like yourself :)

Donations accepted and please bring a blanket to enhance the comfort of your experience!


Much love,


Brian

[masked])

Contact: [masked]

results.name: Hearing the Heart Sound Healing with Brian and Sarah

results.description:
Join us for kickoff weekend with discount tickets at Bretton Woods. Mt Washington usually blesses Bretton Woods with plenty of early snow fall and for the last three years we had fresh powder to ride!

Meet at the Makusue Ski House Friday night around 9pm and get to know some of the members.

Saturday morning they will be selling discount tickets upstairs at the Bretton Woods lodge to all guests of the house. CASH ONLY- You must have your EICSL Guest Pass or ID.

Spend the rest of the day Skiing, Riding, Racing and meet some great people to spend the season with. This is a great mountain to enjoy some early season runs.

Guest Fees will be $50 for the weekend and discount tickets to Bretton Woods are $25. CASH ONLY! During designated sale time. (If you are late you will have to pay full price.)

Meals will most likely be offered for the low price of $25 (Breakfast Sat & Sun, Dinner Sat) Bring or purchase lunch at the mountain.

I will follow up all yes RSVPs with an email and phone call with more details about the weekend, and please let us know by Dec 10th.

We hope to see you up there. Think Snow!!

**The Makusue Ski House, located in North Conway, NH, is only minutes from Cranmore, Wildcat, Attitash and Black Mountains. Come be our guest for the weekend at only $25 a night per person (The Makusue Ski Club is a not-for-profit club with all $ put back into the house to cover expenses.) Visit Makusue.org for more information or email us!**

results.description:
**For this weekend we are only accepting RSVP's for a 2 night stay**

Join us for a fun filled weekend of skiing, snowboarding, racing, and events during the season kick-off weekend. It's a weekend which always proves to be among the best in the White Mountain Valley.  Be sure to sign up early since this sells out quickly every year.

We welcome new and returning guests to the Brettl-Hupfers. It's a great chance to meet and socialize with our members and guests, visit our club ski house, and enjoy everything the White Mountain Valley offers.

The weekend includes 2 nights of lodging, a dinner Saturday, and various activities. 

Highlights:

Saturday Ski Tickets at Bretton Woods for just $25.00 (as a guest of the house)

Evening Events

Saturday breakfast

Catered dinner Saturday night at the Brettl-Hupfers club ski house

And for those hardcore winter fans, our club is about 2 miles from Attitash and close to Wildcat, Cranmore, and Black Mountain. Feel free to ski on Friday or finish off the weekend at one of the local resorts.

More the shopping type? Don't forget that North Conway is down the road offering hundreds of shopping destinations and outlets. Get your ski on - Get your shop on!

The cost for the weekend is $80 (non-member guests), $70 for beta/associate Brettl-Hupfers' members, and $30 for full Brettl-Hupfers' members.  You can pay via PayPal ([masked]). Please write in the subject field “The Best Weekend of Your Life.”  In the message field, be sure to include your name and the name of anyone else you are paying for. 

If you have any questions about the weekend, please email [masked].
results.name: The Best Weekend of Your Life!!!!

results.description:
Join us for our weekly weekend run! We'll be meeting in Back Bay and logging some miles around Boston. All paces and runner levels are welcome! 

During the winter months, we'll be meeting at the Boston Marathon RunBase on Boylston street for our Saturday runs. They have lockers and showers available for your use though you'll need to provide your own lock if you plan to use a locker. 

Please post your desired pace and distance when you RSVP. 

For this week, we have two routes. A five mile route, and a 10 mile route. Both routes begin with runners taking Fairfield Street to the esplanade and then heading east along the river to the Science Museum, before crossing over into Cambridge. Runners then have the option of looping through Lechmere Canal Park (doing so adds about 1/3 mile) before heading west along the Cambridge side of the Charles. For the shorter route, runners will return to Boston over the Mass. Ave bridge and then cross the Fairfield Street footbridge and take Fairfield back to the start. For the longer route, runners will continue on the Cambridge side to the River Street Bridge before crossing back over. Those looking to run the full 10 will continue to the Arlington Street footbridge and then do a partial loop of the Public Garden (see the map). Anyone looking to do 8 can easily cut the longer run by taking the Fairfield footbridge back to the start. 5 mile route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6763575
8/10 mile route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6763583

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Lafayette and Liberty. We will use Old Bridle Path to first reach Lafayette and then then Franconia Ridge Trail to reach Lincoln. From there we will use Falling Waters Trail to return to the trailhead. The AMC's Greenleaf Hut is closed for the season.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 8.9 miles and climb about 4,200 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 30 minutes to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/6-Mt-Lafayette-5260--7-Mt-Lincoln-5089


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.160747571000456&lon=-71.64432749599968#.VjgreYTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION (E.G. KAHTOOLA MICROSPIKES OR HILLSOUND TRAIL CRAMPONS), AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Falling Waters Trailhead which is located on the east side of 93 N north of Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 137 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 7 minutes to drive there. 

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/AuuXaoQoSqN2


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.how_to_find_us: Gray Toyota Highlander or Maroon Honda Accord.
results.name: NH4K ... Lafayette and Lincoln (INTERMEDIATE)

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

results.description:
Do you have just 2 HOURS to give to help others??????

The Wish Project's  major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  I've organized this with WONDERFUL  Meet Up Volunteers in the past & THIS IS FUN! And, "MANY HANDS DO MAKE LIGHT WORK!!! "  I don't know how you feel - But, I ALWAYS feel great when I'm helping others!

If there are enough of us, we usually go somewhere nearby for coffee/brunch & to chat when we leave at 11:00! I've enclosed ( at the bottom of the description) a photo taken at one of our meet ups!

http://thewishproject.org/

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT: If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending. WOMEN: Please do NOT  enter with a purse.  THE WISH PROJECT IS NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR LOST/STOLEN ITEMS

http://thewishproject.org/

*PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty and give her a head count.  She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, PLEASE be considerate to take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks : -)
results.how_to_find_us: We all meet up inside the front lobby just before 9:00
results.name: VOLUNTEER @ The Wish Project/ Lowell

group.name: Meeting & Greeting in So. NH & the Merrimack Valley :)

results.description:
Our last hike to Buck Hill had to misfortune of having driving rain and 40 degree temperatures.  This should be much nicer.

Join L.L.Bean Dedham for a hike up to Buck Hill in the Blue Hills.  Arguably the nicest view in the Blue Hills, it is an open granite summit with 360 degrees of the entire area, including the Boston skyline and the harbor islands.

The entire roundtrip is around 4.5 miles, with two steep, but very manageable sections.  Bring hiking worthy footwear, water for three hours, bug repellent, sunglasses and weather appropriate clothing.

Sign up at www.llbean.com/dedham (the name of the hike is "Blue Hills Observation Tower" in the system, but we'll go to Buck Hill).  Meet at the Houghton's Pond parking lot.
results.how_to_find_us: Anne will be your guide.  Meet at the benches at the side of the parking lot near the snack stand.  The Houghton's Pond lot is the LARGE lot, just down the street from the State Police Barracks, near the pond.
results.name: Hike to Buck Hill in the Blue Hills

results.description:
We are holding a day-long, hands-on algorithmic trading workshop on December 12th. 

To RSVP, please click here. 


In addition to our regular meetups, we will be holding a series of instructional workshops over the coming months, that will walk through beginner to advanced concepts in quantitative finance and algorithmic trading. 

This introductory level workshop will:

• Give you the ability to create and backtest your own basic trading strategies.

• Show you algorithmic trading tools to use.

• Teach you how to correct for some of the statistical biases that can disrupt analysis.

The curriculum has been vetted and used to teach lectures by professors at top-tier universities, including: Harvard, MIT Sloan, and Stanford.

Prerequisites to Attend

Attendees should have beginner knowledge of Python and college level Math experience.

Reserve your Spot

Tickets for The Workshop are: $675. Breakfast, lunch, and snacks will be provided. 

Space is limited and spots will be on a first come, first serve basis. We are keeping The Quantopian Workshop intentionally small in order to give attendees the best hand-on learning experience. 

For more information and to RSVP, please click here. 

Agenda

8:45am: Breakfast

9:00 - 10:00: Introduction to Algorithmic Trading

10:00 - 10:30: Overview of Quantopian Platform

10:30 - 11:00: Introduction to the Research Environment

11:00 -11:30: Lecture: Pairs Trading

11:30 -12:00: Exercise: Find Your Own Pairs

12:00 - 1:00: Lunch

1:00 - 2:00: Exercise: Backtesting

2:00 - 2:30: Lecture: Overfitting

2:30 - 4:30: Exercise: Design Your Own Strategy

4:30 - 5:00: Wrap Up

The Lecturer

The workshop has been developed by Delaney Granizo-Mackenzie, engineer and academic lead at Quantopian, whose focus is on the intersection of computer science, statistics, and finance. 

His background includes seven years of bioinformatics research and delivering lectures at schools including Harvard and MIT. 

Have a question or a comment?

Reach out to Delaney at [masked]. He would love to hear from you! You can also visit us at: www.quantopian.com.

RSVP

For more information and to RSVP, please click here.
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is on Arch Street. We are on the 5th floor.
results.name: The Quantopian Workshops: Introduction to Algorithmic Trading

results.description:
Hi All! Belle Isle Marsh Reservation is a unique little spot in East Boston. We may run solely on the gravel loop around it, and take in the picturesque views, or may venture a little farther out, depending on the participants' preferences. For those coming from Jeffries Point/Eagle Hill, Suffolk Downs Blue Line stop is a two minute walk down Bennington Street. Cheers, Ilya

results.description:
Meet at the lot by Senior Center (see picture below).

Join for a beautiful walk around the Ashland Reservoir.  Plan for up to four hours.  Not sure of mileage but it is an awesome walk, plus should be nice with crisp air. It should be approximately at least five miles.  We will walk  at a pace of approximately 2.5 miles/hour with breaks as needed.  Will update if microspikes needed if ice by that time.  Expect lots of uplifted tree roots with rock, plus leaves, and mud.  There may be snow/ice if cold enough temperatures.


This is a group event. We start together, stay together and finish together. We follow the leader’s instructions. We support each other should circumstances require teamwork. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: Trekker events are not  for high-maintenance individuals. 

For a trail map, go to:

http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-north/ashland-state-park.html

Here are the directions from the Mass DCR web page:

Directions:From North or South: Rte. 495 to "Main Street" Hopkinton exit, continue east on Main Street. Before Hopkinton Center Rt. 135 comes in on the left, follow Rt. 135 east approx. 3 miles to park Entrance is on the right.

Since Entrance to park is closed, please part in Senior Center pictured above.

Wear hiking Boots, bring, water/snacks.

 By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below: 
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason


We hike in light rain, showers or light snow, but heavy precipitation or extreme weather cancels.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events. 

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. There are no exceptions, regardless of the size of the group or how awesome your dog is..

Trekker membership is open to adults only and our events are designed for adults. We do not allow children @ our events. 

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.

results.description:
** Edit: So sorry to have to change this again, but Emma from the gallery can only come at 10am, so I am changing this to 10am. Hope you can still make it!**

Hi All,


Since many of us didn't get to go to South Station last Saturday, let's sketch it again!

 With the cold weather this is a great inside site to draw.


We will be collecting artwork again this Saturday, this is the last chance for submit something for the show (FYI, Target is a great place for cheap frames, and Blick is having a sale). New members are welcome to participate in the show as well, with two -thee framed urban sketches. Emma from the gallery at Peabody will collect the work this weekend.
This is the calendar:

Delivery of artwork: December 12, 2015 MT Exhibition Opening Reception: December 17,[masked]pm Free and open to the public, food and wine provided by ArcWorks, though any desired donations or assistance are welcome and appreciated with advance notice. Exhibition run dates: December 17, 2015 – January 23, 2016 Gallery open M-F 10-4 and Sat 10-3 Artwork pick-up: January 25 -26, 2016

The look and feel of the new South Station, designed by the architectural firm of Shepley, Rutan and Coolidge, was inspired by the style of famed Boston architect Henry Hobson Richardson, most known for his design of Boston’s Trinity Church. Richardson had also designed nine railroad stations for the Boston and Albany Railroad and had collaborated with famed Boston landscape designer Frederick Law Olmstead to design the landscaping along the Boston and Albany line.

Norcross Brothers, who were contractors on most of Richardson’s projects and also owners of several quarries that supplied granite for the architects, was chosen to build the new station. Construction of this major undertaking took about two years.

The building itself was comprised of five stories in neo-classical revival style. Three double doors, a design element that still exists today, opened up into the newly designed Dewey Square, named for Civil War and Spanish American War Hero George Dewey.

The station’s exterior clock, manufactured by the Edward Howard Clock Company of Roxbury, was topped by an imposing eagle statue with an eight-foot wingspan. The clock stands as the only remaining double, three-legged escapement mechanism in New England.

Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.

This is a great way to get into running, introduce your friends to the group, or just start your Saturday on a high note.  All ages and levels welcome.

If you are hesitating to come, keep in mind that nearly every week we have beginning runners who use a run/walk/run technique.  If you take walk breaks you will probably not be alone, and it's the best way to get into running, so come on out!

results.description:
Hi all, 

A friend of mine from back home recently has been diagnosed with a condition known as cardiomyopathy, and has been given a Left Ventricle Assist Device or LVAD to aid her heart function until she receives a heart transplant. 

This Halloween, we will be hosting a costume-themed charity workout to show our support for Olivia, and raise money for her various medical and living expenses. To fully understand why we are hosting this charity, you must first understand her story:

From her sister, Sofia Hart:

"Olivia always thrived to do the best she could. Being gifted with horse back riding as our hobby (or life passion) growing up, she was incredibly fearless and passionate with everything in her. She was also happy to be a Vineyarder during her years playing Hockey and Soccer, representing the place she loved most, home. Her determination was unstoppable on and off horse back, the field, and the ice. These characteristics followed her through her life growing into adulthood. 

As a recent University of Vermont graduate, she did just the same in her studies. When she felt defeated, she would do everything in her power to figure out what went wrong, and how she could fix her mistakes. While at her graduation, tears of joy were brought to my eyes as she smiled receiving her achievements and laughed and hugged with friends. Not only was she proud of herself, but she was even more proud of the people who surrounded her and their accomplishments too.

These qualities and characteristics went even further into the workplace. As a former employee of the Homeport Resturant, she used the skills and experience she learned there and carried it to the Seafood Shanty. Each and every job she has held has meant so much to her. Good days and bad days, she always would talk so highly of her job, especially for how dedicated she was to each establishment. 

Through hardwork, fearlessness, dedication and most importantly, love, Olivia has gained a rather admirable reputation growing up on Martha's Vineyard for 22 years, and at UVM during her college years. 

These amazing qualities and characteristics have not diminished one bit during these tough times. Her spirit is incredibly high, and she shocks us on a daily basis how positive her attitude is. I can not imagine being in her place, and handling the news she gets on a daily basis. Although she has received bad news many times, her positive outlook has not changed. Olivia is determined as ever, looking toward the brightest future."

Here is more on Olivias condition, with a post from her Facebook page:

"So here it is. On the 9th I was transported to Massachusetts General Hospital and diagnosed with a condition known as cardiomyopathy which is a disease of the heart muscle. There is damage to both the right and left portions but the majority of the damage is in the left ventricle. It wasn't until I had a cardiac MRI that the doctors realized my condition was most likely irreversible. The doctors believe it either began years ago when I most likely contracted a viral infection that attacked my heart or may have been something I was born with... the overall cause is unknown. My age enabled me to live and thrive with the condition until a couple of months ago. Currently, I am in the process of being placed on the heart transplant list, which I will hopefully be accepted to by the end of the week, and will receive a new heart by the start of the new year. For now that is about all that we know."

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

results.description:
I've been hearing a lot from seasoned business owners and non-profit organizers that they find getting people to pay attention to their message difficult. And I hear a lot of confusion around the best tools or methods to use to help grow their audience. 

Given that most every enterprise succeeds or fails based on it's ability to create a loyal following, this is a big problem. So I've been really trying to figure this out. 

What makes anyone start paying attention to the work of a creative business or a social enterprise?

I decided it wasn't a tool problem. It wasn't even a method problem (although the tools and methods you use are certainly a factor).

It was an enrollment problem. 

Specifically, it was a misunderstanding about the type of engagement required to earn anyone's attention and interest in your project. 

For this meetup we'll discuss the way you talk about what you do and the the key difference between the type of communication that creates engagement and those that continually fall short - so you can join the conversation you want to be in for your business - and say something different.

Greetings Photographers! I am back at last from my travels and ready to teach again. The weather for Saturday will be almost like summer, so let's head to the beach. This is a crazy, busy time of year. Treat yourself to a mini retreat and soak up the fresh air by the sea. You will be amazed at how relaxed and calm this photo field trip will make you feel. 

This picturesque, charming New England village is often the setting for movies and the source of inspiration artists of all types. Your inspiring, creative, photo experience will have three segments: First, we will explore the architecture  of the historic village, then move on to the  harbor boats and marsh area, and when the light is just perfect, we will walk up to the famous Singing Beach to photograph seascapes with the dramatic rocky coastline.


We will go slow, see with fresh eyes, and enjoy spending the day with a fun group of people who simply love photography.  Take a break from the world and just be present to the beauty for the day. You will feel the stress melting away. Best of all, you will learn how to take better pictures by the end of the day.

Singing Beach located at Manchester by the Sea.

 It is a 20 minute walk from the town to the beach so please keep this in mind when deciding if this field trip is for you.

Rocky Coast at Singing Beach offers great dramatic compositions.

Some of the topics I will cover in the workshop will be:

• How to slow down, be more present and really see with a fresh, creative eye. 

• How to compose subjects within the frame and in relationship to each other using creative points of view and rules of thirds. 

• How to use visual elements of color, light, texture, and motion to evoke emotion and tell a story when photographing architecture and landscapes.

• How to choose the most compelling segment of the horizon for your landscape photos. Working with creative perspectives and dynamic viewpoints.

• Some basic camera operation tips will be offered if you need them to get off the Auto Setting and take photos that are properly exposed and in focus. It will be fun to capture the crashing waves at the beach by playing with your shutter speeds to freeze the action.


I hope you will join us and discover how to capture the true beauty of a place. Discover how to see the hidden structure of the scene. Once you see it, you can capture it in your photos. You will immediately feel the difference in your photography because they will have more impact and power. 

Harbor and Marsh area.

This is a "no technical jargon zone", so if you're a total beginner, I promise that you will feel at ease and totally comfortable in this relaxed and fun setting. I provide individual coaching and suggestions so you will improve immediately. 

If you are more advanced and have attended several of my programs already, I will have extra credit assignments to challenge you. Bring your macro lens if you have one.

Macro Shot of Seaweed

Logistics: You can drive and meet us at the MBTA parking lot in Manchester, or you can go on the train from North Station. The train departs at 10:15. I will organize things so anyone taking the train can find each other and sit together. We will be in the first car of the train. I have taken some great photos while on the train so be sure to get a window seat. I will share some tips for how to shoot from a moving train. 

Photo taken out the train window on the way to Manchester by the Sea.

The tuition for the program is $65.00 including handouts, one on one instruction, and assignments. This is a class so be prepared to work hard and play hard, so charge up those batteries. This is a great way to really focus and improve your skills. More details about what to bring in terms of camera gear will be provided once I have the full class list. All levels and camera types welcome for this one. I am limiting the class size to only 10. 

You can bring a brown bag lunch, or pick up a sandwich or chowder to go at several spots in town. Weather permitting we will picnic outside in the park and have a lively discussion about our photography. Then we will head up to the beach. 

The train back to Boston departs at 5:31. Class ends at 4:30 and we will have social hour and refreshments at a pub next to the train station if you want to join for that you should bring cash so it is easy to just pay for exactly what you order.

Let's take advantage of this warm spell and enjoy the day! Hope to see you on Saturday, RSVP now to save your spot!

Suzanne

results.description:
Join us for the December 2015 Meetup!

ATC THEMES:


1. Stained Glass


2. Artist's Choice


DEMO/ACTIVITY:  Lots of things! Participate in our 9th annual Goodie Bag Exchange. Read the details by clicking here. Then sign up by Dec. 1: Just click here.  We may also have a Yankee Trader swap, a raffle, and more!

WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we have loaner tools.

POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like.

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: You're welcome to bring items to give away or sell to other Meetup members onsite. Just remember to remove anything that doesn't get picked up or sold--we can't leave anything behind.

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart; it covers our costs for the day. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. Cash is preferred; small bills are greatly appreciated. If payment is a hardship, please let the organizer know--we can work it out.

RSVPs: Please RSVP "yes" to attend; that way, we'll have an approximate headcount, and you'll receive all notifications about the Meetup! If your plans change, and you will be unable to attend, please change your RSVP to "no" no later than 24 hours before the start of the Meetup, so we'll know not to expect you. Anyone who cancels within 24 hours, regardless of the reason, will need to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

Hope to see you there!
results.name: NE ATC+ December 2015 Meetup: Holiday Party, Art Fair & More!

results.description:
From November 29 to December 12, world leaders will meet in Paris to negotiate a new global climate treaty. This is their 21st attempt, and we already know that even if they reach an agreement, it won’t be nearly as strong as we need it to be. 2015 is on track to be the hottest year on record, and unprecedented storms, floods and droughts are happening around the world. We are running out of time, and we must create an unstoppable grassroots movement for real climate action.

On December 12, people will come together from every corner of New England to call for bold climate solutions that create secure union jobs, strengthen community power and help build a more resilient future. Can you join us?

What: Jobs, Justice and Climate: Defend New England’s Future
When: Saturday, Dec 12, 1-3 pm
Where: Boston Common, Boston

We’ll lift up the voices of New England's organized labor, immigrant rights, racial justice, and climate justice groups as we call for jobs, justice and climate action together. You won’t want to miss it!
We’re hoping that December 12 will be one of the biggest climate actions in New England history. Can you join us?
results.name: Jobs, Justice & Climate: Defend New England’s Future

results.description:
BOOK:

Bombay Stories by Saadat Hasan Manto

Only 9 copies in the Minuteman Library System.

DESCRIPTION:

A collection of classic, yet shockingly contemporary, short stories set in the vibrant world of mid-century Bombay, from one of India’s greatest writers.
Arriving in 1930s Bombay, Saadat Hasan Manto discovered a city like no other. A metropolis for all, and an exhilarating hub of license and liberty, bursting with both creative energy and helpless despondency. A journalist, screenwriter, and editor, Manto is best known as a master of the short story, and Bombay was his lifelong muse. Vividly bringing to life the city’s seedy underbelly—the prostitutes, pimps, and gangsters that filled its streets—as well as the aspiring writers and actors who arrived looking for fame, here are all of Manto’s Bombay-based stories, together in English for the very first time. By turns humorous and fantastical, Manto’s tales are the provocative and unflinching lives of those forgotten by humanity.
results.how_to_find_us: Book on the table
results.name: Bombay Stories by Saadat Hasan Manto at Bukhara, Jamaica Plain

results.description:
This year we're holding our traditional Solstice gathering in December, rather than just after the calendar New Year. On December 12 at 12:30 pm, we will hold our annual Greater Boston Humanists SOLSTICE LUNCHEON celebrating the true reason for the holiday 'season': our Earth's tilt and the Solstice bringing lengthening days in the northern hemisphere!

We'll dine together, at the Humanist Hub in Harvard Square, Cambridge. The food will be catered from Andreas House of Pizza, with chicken shishkebab, rice and Greek salad, coffee, drinks and dessert, for $16 - bring exact change or a check to GBH. (A vegetarian dish option can be provided but you must let me know directly by email by Friday).

After lunch, we'll hear from our special speaker Kiril Sinkel, who will speak on "The Human Condition: How to live one's life in an indifferent universe," about the philosophy of John Kekes. Speaker Kiril Sinkel is on the board of the Philosophy Cafe and a regular moderator at its meetings. His interests are primarily at the intersection of philosophy and science and include philosophy of the mind, cosmology and the history of science and their impact on society and ethics. He is particularly interested in the foundations of a secular philosophy that is consistent with scientific understanding, while at the same time acknowledging and promoting human needs and values.  

The event will last until approximately 3:30 pm. Free PARKING will be available in the Littauer Lot of Harvard University near the Science Center, from which The Hub is a walk across Harvard Yard and down JFK Street. (Enter the Dworkin Science Quadrangle from Oxford St. and proceed to the end of the road to the parking area near the Science Center behind Littauer Library. If nervous, leave a note in your dashboard that you are at the Humanist event at PBH.)

Please let us know if you're going to attend by RSVPing my email address and ALSO saying you are coming on MeetUp, so we will order the correct amount of food (and whether you need the vegetarian option).

Thanks, and Happy Humanist Holidays (don't miss other secular activities and options this holiday season, including the Hub's own programming every week)!
results.name: GBH Annual Solstice Luncheon w/Speaker Kiril Sinkel "The Human Condition"

results.description:
Queridos compañeros,

Muchas gracias a todos por vuestra participación en la lectura de poesía del sábado pasado.  ¡Y una cordial bienvenida a Beatriz, Jerry y Orna!

El sábado 12 de diciembre nos reuniremos en Schoenhof´s para comentar "El amante japonés" de Isabel Allende.  La sinopsis del libro es la siguiente:  www.casadellibro.com/libro-el-amante-japones/[masked]/[masked] El libro está disponible en muchas librerías como Harvard Bookstore o Barnes & Noble. 

En enero, volveremos con unos de los pesos pesados de la literatura hispanoamericana con "El héroe discreto" de Mario Vargas Llosa.  La sinopsis es  siguiente: www.casadellibro.com/libro-el-heroe-discreto/[masked]/[masked] El libro estará disponible en Schoenhof´s a un precio de $22.36 con nuestro descuento.  Si tenéis intención de comprarlo en Schoenhof´s, por favor avisadme cuánto antes para que le informe a Dean cuántos ejemplares vamos a necesitar.

Tal como comentamos en la última reunión, en diciembre festejaremos las navidades con una fiesta de traje.  Cada uno que quiera puede traer algo para comer o para tomar.  Yo sin duda aportaré algo de vinito y algunos pastelitos ricos.... ojalá mis contactos contrabandistas españoles no me fallen.... ;-) No dudéis en avisarme si tenéis ideas......

Ya que nos gustó tanto el año pasado, vamos a repetir un Yankee Swap en la fiesta.  Cada uno que quiera participar, que traiga un regalito que no supere los $15/20 dólares de valor y jugaremos. 

Por último, como ya os comenté, en la reunión del 12 de diciembre vamos a tener la oportunidad de regalar libros en español a niños de entre 1 y 5 años de edad cuyas familias no tienen los recursos económicos suficientes para comprarlos.  Esto supone no sólo un regalo muy especial para el niño sino también para su madre ya que enriquece y fortalece el vínculo entre los dos.  Vamos a donar los libros a través del programa de Madres Jóvenes de Roca donde trabajo Mary Liz.  Si queréis donar pero no tenéis tiempo para comprar los libros, aceptaremos también contribuciones de dinero y nos ocuparemos nosotros de comprar y entregar los libros.  Os rogaría nos trajeseis los libros envueltos en papel por favor. Si tenéis cualquier pregunta sobre este rograma, no dejéis de hacérmela llegar.  ¡Muchísimas gracias de antemano a todos por vuestra participación en esta buena causa y a Mary Liz por su ayuda a coordinarla!

¡Os deseo a todos un feliz día de Acción de Gracias……lleno de mucha alegría…..y pocos empachos de pavo! ;-)

¡Espero que os gusten las lecturas!

¡Hasta diciembre!

Un fuerte abrazo,

Mark
results.how_to_find_us: La reunión se celebrará en la sala al fondo de la librería.
results.name: En diciembre: Isabel Allende, caridad y fiesta

results.description:
Welcome, beginners! Want to learn to code? Here's where to start!

We'll do two fun sessions:

- In session 1, we'll play How to Train Your Robot (https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/34702090/drtechniko/How_To_Train_Your_Robot.pdf) and get started with Scratch. In Scratch, we'll create a sprite and move it around the screen.

- In session 2, we'll go deeper into Scratch. We'll set up a treasure and some obstacles and train your sprite to get the treasure. Then we'll turn it into a fun game.

Prerequisites


1) The Scratch Offline Editor is installed and runs on your laptop. To install the Scratch Offline Editor, follow these instructions https://scratch.mit.edu/scratch2download/ .

With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

results.description:
Cannabis Society is helping promote Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance's Patient Night in Quincy.  The event will bring together the entire cannabis community including Cannabis Society's members and leadership to engage in some social networking and learn about the Massachusetts medical marijuana program and its bright future. Refreshments will be provided.

Featured Speakers

Dr. Jordan Tishler 

Lead Physician at InhaleMD

Talk Title: Medical Marijuana 101

Talk Synopsis: Dr. Tishler will discuss how to become a patient and caregiver in Massachusetts and how to properly use marijuana as medicine.

Connect with Dr. Tishler: https://www.linkedin.com/in/jordan-tishler-md-93368073


Nichole Snow

Executive Director of Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance

Talk Title: Safe Access in Massachusetts

Talk Synopsis: Nichole Snow will overview the medical marijuana program in Massachusetts including becoming a patient or caregiver and how to access Registered Marijuana Dispensaries.

Connect with Nichole Snow: https://www.linkedin.com/in/nichole-snow-39988332


Shanel Lindsay

Founder & President of Ardent Cannabis

Talk Title: Decarboxylation Science

Talk Synopsis: Shanel Lindsay will explore the science of Decarboxylation and how it led to the development of a new product and precision decarboxylator.

Connect with Shanel Lindsay: https://www.linkedin.com/in/shanellindsay


Michael Bourque

Founder & President of CannaKorp

Talk Title: Vaporization

Talk Synopsis: Learn all about vaporization from Michael Bourque of CannaKorp and the different types of vaporizers along with his new invention CannaCloud™.

Connect with Michael Bourque: https://www.linkedin.com/in/mbourque

About Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance

The Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance (MPAA) is a coalition of medical marijuana patients, their family members and caregivers, medical professionals, and public health groups that supports safe access to medical cannabis for patients with a doctor’s recommendation.

MPAA brought the 2012 medical cannabis ballot initiative to the voters, and has since been working to ensure implementation of the law is completed in a manner that works for individual patients and communities as a whole.

http://www.compassionforpatients.com/


Patient Night is Sponsored By

Ermont

Ermont, Inc. is currently moving through the Department of Public Health registration process and working with the city of Quincy during the renovation and construction phase of the project. They are committed to opening a best-in-class medical marijuana dispensary to provide high-quality laboratory-tested medicine to registered patients. Their projected date of opening is January of 2016.

http://www.ermontinc.org/

InhaleMD 

Dr. Tishler is a leading expert in the field of Medical Cannabis therapeutics.  As an Emergency Physician, he has treated countless alcoholics and drug users. His observation that he had never seen a Cannabis overdose lead Dr. Tishler to delve deeply into the science of Cannabis safety and treatment.  After years of research and learning, Dr. Tishler brings his knowledge, reason, and caring to patients here at Inhale Medical Consulting, and through his advocacy work at the local and national levels.


http://inhalemd.com/


CannaBranders

CannaBranders is a marketing and branding agency dedicated to the cannabis industry, so they know just how to make your unique personality come to life. They pride themselves in helping your business skyrocket in this exciting time. So let them help you become a memorable and functional face in the industry.

https://www.cannabranders.com/

Canna Care Docs

Canna Care Docs, a division of MedEVal Corp., qualifies patients into medical marijuana programs in Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Maine, Connecticut, Delaware and the District of Columbia.

Canna Care Docs is committed to the medicinal value cannabis brings to your holistic healthcare treatment and providing safe and compliant access into medical marijuana programs. At Canna Care Docs you will spend time with a caring, non-judgmental medical professional qualifying your condition for medical marijuana and discussing cannabis as it relates to your specific needs.

http://cannacaredocs.com/



Think Patient Night Might Benefit Your City or Town?

MPAA plans on having Patient Night once a month in various locations around Massachusetts. If you're interested in sponsoring this event or supporting future Patient Night events in different locations around the state, please email Nichole Snow at [masked]. 



Legal Disclaimer  

Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at our local Cannabis Society community events do not necessarily express the opinion or views of the Cannabis Society organization and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors at our local events. The Cannabis Society does not distribute cannabis.

The Cannabis Society is Growing  

Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.
results.name: Patient Night (Quincy)

results.description:
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/intro-to-schematic-capture-and-circuit-layout-tickets-19445157991

This course will teach the basics of schematic capture and printed circuit board design using Eagle PCB. Eagle is a full featured, free tool used by many in the maker community. This introductory course will walk students through the basics of creating a schematic from existing library components, creating a printed circuit board outline, placing components and routing the board. Finally, all students will have the opportunity to have their board fabricated with OSH Park or Seeed Studio. Several simple circuit designs will be available to choose from. Student should bring their own laptops so they can setup Eagle PCB in class. Laptops will be provided to those who need them. Please contact the instructor before the class if you will require a laptop.

This is an basic course but participants should have some understanding of the fundamentals of electricity and circuits. We recommend the Lowell Makes Arduino class as a prerequisite for those with no electronics or microcontroller experience.
results.name: Intro to Schematic Capture and Circuit Layout

results.description:
AS PARIS NEGOTIATIONS END, HUNDREDS WILL RALLY IN BOSTON FOR JOBS, JUSTICE & CLIMATE ACTION

FREE: Climate Justice Rally on Boston Common
AT END of Climate Talks in Paris (to hear what they said)

What: As the UN negotiations on climate change in Paris come to close, hundreds of people from across New England will gather in Boston for a rally and march to demand jobs, justice, and bold climate action.

When: December 12, 1-3 pm

Where: Rally at Parkman Bandstand on the Boston Common, followed by a march through downtown and a rally at the State House

Who: A diverse coalition including a dozen labor unions and workers’ rights groups, nearly 50 climate and environmental groups, and nearly 40 faith and social justice groups (see full list here)

Speakers include:

Adrian Ventura, New Bedford Workers Center
Reverend Margaret Bullitt-Jonas, Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts
John Robbins, President, Council on American-Islamic Relations of Massachusetts
Sherri Mitchell, Executive Director, Land Peace Foundation and member of Maine Penobscot Tribe
Derek Pelotte, 350 Massachusetts for a Better Future
Fred Small, Interfaith Coalition for Climate Action
Why: On December 11, world leaders will close the 21st round of international climate negotiations in Paris, France. Regardless of what happens in Paris, it’s clear that bold action on climate will be needed here in New England and around the world. On December 12, hundreds of people will call on New England governors and legislators to promote climate solutions that create secure, well-paying union jobs and enhance community resiliency. With climate change already displacing millions around the world, participants will also call on local leaders to stand with immigrants and refugees and speak out against racism and xenophobia.

ENDORSERS TO DATE:
ORGANIZED LABOR AND WORKERS' RIGHTS

Howdy horror fans!

First let me apologize, it has been a while since the last meetup.  The good news, this meetup makes up for that ten times over!  Our friends at All Things Horror have partnered with the Etheria Film Festival, and are bringing it to our own Somerville Theatre.  If you haven't been, then you are missing out, this event showcases emerging female talent creating some fantastic horror and thriller indie films.  

Check out the line up, and purchase tickets here


Looks like 1 feature length film and 8 shorts.  The only piece in the lineup that I have seen was Slut, and it was fantastic, can't wait to see the rest!

So, come and join me Saturday the 12th, the fest runs from 2 - 6pm, afterward we can grab some food and drink and talk about all that was awesome from the fest, and horror in general.  If you can't make the showing on the 12th, there is an earlier run on the evening of Friday the 11th.

Hope to see you there!

-TY

Design for Eternity – Event details HERE. Order tickets HERE. Part of the MFA fall lecture series HERE. 

December 12th, 2-3pm

Museum of Fine Arts

Mabel Louise Riley Seminar Room (Meeting Room 156)

Tickets MFA Members - $10 (Nonmembers $12.00): Call[masked] or visit any MFA ticket desk.

:: :: ::

Joanne Pillsbury, Andrall E. Pearson Curator, Art of the Ancient Americas, The Metropolitan Museum of Art and author, Design for Eternity

From the first millennium B.C. until the arrival of Europeans in the 16th century, artists from across the ancient Americas created small-scale architectural effigies to be placed in the tombs of important individuals. Although described as models, these effigies were created not so much as reflections or prototypes of existing structures, but rather as critical, conceptual components of funerary practice and beliefs about an afterlife.

Hear from author and curator Joanne Pillsbury as she shares the insights from Design for Eternity, the first publication in English to explore these architectural works, providing new insights into ancient American design and how it reflected the practices of daily life.

Book signing to follow.
results.name: Design for Eternity

results.description:
{Do you seek greater inner peace?  Peacemakers is a group that helps you look at what "peace" means to you and helps you find how to create more peace in your life.} 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

... provide you an opportunity to let go of tension, upset, and judgements so that you can experience greater peace.

Many of us have accepted living with tensions in our bodies, with upsets spoiling our mood at unexpected times, with judgments sneaking in. 

Come join us as we practice living our lives more peacefully. 

Peace is not being passive, submissive or indifferent. Peace is an active consciousness that we can learn to enter into, enriching our individual lives, our social situations and the world at large. 

During this evening, we will practice discovering the peace that is always present within us -- no matter what else is going on inside us or outside us in the world.   As we practice recognizing our inner core of peace, we become increasingly able to choose to live in that consciousness of inner peace, even at difficult times of our lives. 

We will look at where we unconsciously practice "against-ness", and learn to let go of that feeling of against-ness, to better work with reality and with the people who surround us. As we let go of "against-ness", we also let go of the upset feelings, prejudices, judgments, tenseness, etc. 

This meeting is sponsored by the Institute of Individual and World Peace (www.iiwp.org)

To Prepare ....

1) When do you feel "against-ness"? 


2) What are the physical signs of your against-ness? (e.g., tightness in throat)  

3) What emotional signs or mental beliefs could be signs of against-ness?

4) How could you be more effective if you were in peace even when bad things happened?

Our Leaders This Evening

David Jenkins aspires to live his life more and more in peace. He considers himself a student of living the four principles of peace in his life. This is his highest priority. He is overjoyed to have been involved with the Peacemaker Project for several years. It expands peace in a quiet, loving way, one person at a time.

Emily Page delights in finding joy with others and as an inner process one moment at a time.She's been assisting with Boston Area PeaceMaker Meetings because the simple tools shared go so deep, work so fast and foster such harmony between participants, one session after another. 

Philosophy: The philosophy grounding this work is the realization that peace must start with the individual. One can not fight for peace. If we are going to be a conduit for peace, we must start with ourselves and be in peace. Peace is defined as the absence of againstness. If we can be in peace without being against ourselves or others or situations and encourage others to do the same, then we can be a conduit for peace. 

Facilitators Motivation: We aspire to live our lives more and more in peace. This intention is our highest priority. Participating in these meetings is one way to learn to live our lives more and more in peace. Encouraging others to do the same is strengthening for us all.
results.name: Peacemakers: Create Inner Peace for a Happier Life

results.description:
WINTER REIMAGINED!  http://www.towerhillbg.org/index.php/visit/signature-events/winterreimagined/

COST:  Adult: $12   Senior : $9.00   Group Rate (10+) Adult-$9. Senior- $7

( **This is a special event- Library passes are NOT accepted for admission)

TIME:  Leave ( Merrimack Valley & beyond) by 4:00 ARRIVAL:  5-5:30 pm

Saturdays WINTER REIMAGINED Hours:  11-9pm  ( we should be there by dark)

The most dazzling display of winter lights in Central Massachusetts returns to Tower Hill this winter. Marvel at glittering light displays indoors and out, with fifteen miles of lights, decorated trees, fire-pits, thousands of handcrafted ornaments, live music and more!

Tips for Enjoying Winter Reimagined:
In recent years, more people than ever have been discovering Winter Reimagined and the joy of walking through the gardens while admiring the sparkling lights strung through Tower Hill’s distinguished collection of shrubs, trees, and landscape features. As Winter Reimagined has become increasing popular, we request our visitors to plan extra time for admission and parking. During evening hours, when visitation is highest, we encourage carpooling when possible. We also recommend that VISITORS FRESS WARM and WEAR STURDY SHOES /BOOTS for  outdoor walks around the gardens. To expedite entry at the gate, we encourage non-member visitors to bring exact change for admission (although we do accept major credit cards). 

After strolling through the glowing gardens, visitors are welcome to explore the indoor facilities.

LIVE MUSIC SCHEDULE: The Tedescho Duo will be performing @ 6:00 -8:0 pm

*** PLEASE NOTE: Accessibility during Winter Reimagined
Tower Hill’s INTERIOR  spaces are accessible on foot and by wheelchair. These interior spaces include the Garden Shop, Twigs Café, the Library, the Milton Gallery and the Conservatories. Sturdy footwear is encouraged when strolling through the outdoor gardens. Most of the light show can be accessed by those with limited mobility, though during inclement weather or when snow cover remains on the ground, certain outdoor pathways may become difficult to traverse. However, much of the lighting can be seen from indoor viewing spots, and the main paths around the gardens that host the most lights (the Lawn Garden, Entry Garden, and Winter Garden) are cleared away after each snow storm

* AFTER:  DINE OUT: For anyone interested. I've made a reservation for our group @ Checkerboards Restaurant for 8:15/8:30 ( they are flexible with the time). The address is: 10 TECHNOLOGY DR. HUDSON MA ( Stop & Shop Plaza) This location is on the way back ( if you are taking the highway) and VERY easy to find. It's in a plaza with a large parking lot.  Phone:[masked]-440. checkerboardsrestaurant.com (menu/pricing)

" Checkerboards is a full service family restaurant serving lunch and dinner daily for over twenty years. We specialize in fresh seafood, homemade Italian dishes, steaks, salads, homemade soups, chowders and much more..."

Open since 1999, Organic Garden Cafe is the premier raw vegan restaurant in New England! COMPLIMENTARY TABLE APPETIZERS are provided to the group every 2nd Saturday monthly from 4:00-5:30pm! The menu offers a wide range of choices to delight your appetite including: juices, smoothies, soups, nori-rolls, spring rolls, pad thai, nachos, salads, pizza, burgers, pasta, tacos, gourmet daily specials, and deserts!  www.organicgardencafe.com This is a 'cross-post' from  http://meetup.com/rawboston

Directions from Rte. 128 (including Boston Rte. 93N to Rte 128): Follow Rte 128 North. When Rte 128 North splits to the left from Rte 95, be sure to stay on Rte. 128 "North to Gloucester". Follow Rte 128 to Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right. Note: After Rte. 95 North and Rte. 128 split (north of Rte. 93) the numbering system for exits changes and exit numbers begin decreasing.

Directions from Boston via Rte. 1 [see above for Rte 93N Directions]: Take Rte. 1 North over the the Tobin Bridge. Follow until you see signs for Rte. 128 Gloucester and Rte. 95 North and take that exit. Bear left to take Rte. 128 North and stay on Rte 128 until Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right.

Directions from Salem: Go over the bridge from Salem to Beverly on Rte. 1A. Just after the bridge bear right onto Cabot St. Travel for 1 1/2 miles till you see Cabot Cinema and Organic Garden on the left.

Commuter Rail: 
Newburyport/Rockport Line
